name: Lemmy
tagline: Federated Reddit alternative for open discussions
description: Lemmy is a federated, open-source social media platform serving as a decentralized alternative to Reddit. Built on the ActivityPub protocol, it lets users join any instance (server) and engage with communities across the fediverse—posting content, commenting, upvoting/downvoting, and following topics. Key advantages include no single point of control, reduced censorship risks, and user autonomy. Perfect for privacy-focused users craving community-driven discussions without corporate oversight. It supports self-hosting, enabling anyone to launch their own instance, nurturing a diverse ecosystem of independent communities. Lemmy’s open-source code fosters transparency, allowing developers to contribute and enhance its features continuously.
best_for: Privacy-conscious users, open-source enthusiasts, Reddit alternatives seekers, community moderators

It caters to all skill levels—beginners struggling with syntax to pros speeding up workflows. By converting plain language requests (e.g., “sum column B where column A is ‘active’”) into valid, error-free formulas, it eliminates memorizing hundreds of function rules. It supports common functions like VLOOKUP, SUMIF, COUNTIF, and INDEX-MATCH, with instant previews to verify outputs. Ideal for automating repetitive tasks, reducing errors, and saving time, it’s perfect for students, marketers, small business owners, and regular Google Sheets users.
